Urticaria, atopic and contact dermatitis |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the main principles of treating contact eczema |Description=None |Rubric=Management |Contributors=Nadège Cordel; Frédéric Bérard |Order=18}}The treatment of contact eczema is based on 2 principles: * Avoid contact with the allergen: this is the most important aspect of the treatment (secondary prevention). * Dermocorticoid'', 1 application daily until the eczema has healed, usually about ten days. ** Cream or ointment depending on the site: *** cream (folds or oozing lesion) *** ointment (the rest of the body outside the folds, and on non-oozing lesions). After an eczema flare-up, a ''moisturising cream'' is recommended to combat skin flaking, which follows the inflammatory phase of eczema.

question.question: What are the two main principles of treating contact eczema?
question.option_a: Avoid contact with the allergen and use a moisturizing cream to combat skin flaking
question.option_b: Use a dermatocorticoid cream or ointment and avoid contact with the allergen
question.option_c: Apply a moisturizing cream daily and use a corticosteroid cream as needed
question.option_d: Avoid contact with the allergen and apply a corticosteroid cream or ointment as needed
